repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Third National Program for
            Community Empowerment in Rural Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third National Program
            for Community Empowerment in Rural Areas Project for
            Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk
            to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: capacity
            building of an implementing agency responsible for a
            nationwide Community-Driven Development (CDD) program
            requires substantial time and effort. Capacity building of
            communities is a long-term and iterative process which over
            time may lead to inclusive and transparent decision making.
            Project guidelines (procurement, financial management,
            implementation cycle, etc) have to evolve to take into
            account changing community competencies. Project managers
            must avoid to overload such guidelines and to make them too
            bureaucratic. A robust Management Information System (MIS)
            is essential for a nationwide CDD program. Although the
            project was able to monitor progress against its Key
            Performance Indicator (KPIs) by surveys and studies
            (augmented by processed MIS data), a publicly accessible
            system that presents reliable and regularly updated
            information is needed to instill a culture of accountability
            and transparency at all levels of project implementation.
            Pre-financing of block grants by Government of Indonesia
            (GoI) is effective. This approach was pioneered by the
            project and resulted in a significant reduction in delays in
            disbursement of block grants compared to Program Nasional
            Pemberdayaan Masyarakat (PNPM) rural first and second. The
            quality of facilitators is the main driver of
            community-based project implementation quality.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Third National Program for
            Community Empowerment (PNPM) in Rural Areas - Disaster
            Management Support Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Third National
            Program for Community Empowerment (PNPM) in Rural Areas -
            Disaster Management Support Project for Indonesia is for
            villagers in PNPM-Rural locations to benefit from improved
            socio-economic and local governance conditions. The grants
            will help finance the costs associated with the Government
            of Indonesia's (GoI) disaster management efforts at the
            community level, including facilitating recovery from the
            recent natural disasters that struck the country in October
            2010. Additional financing being provided to each project
            would continue to finance the same types of activities
            currently financed under those projects, but in
            disaster-affected areas. The closing date for the additional
            financing for the three projects will be December 31, 2012.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Third National Program for
            Community Empowerment in Rural Areas Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Third National
            Program for Community Empowerment in Rural Areas Project is
            to reduce poverty and improve local-level governance in
            Indonesia through the provision of investment resources to
            support productive proposals developed by communities, using
            a participatory planning process. Negative impacts include:
            air pollution from vehicles; flooding due to improper
            sitting of bridge; increase in airborne dust; noise
            pollution; increasing erosion; and diverting the flow of
            rain water. Mitigation measures include: 1) selecting an
            alignment that reduces environmental disturbances; 2)
            utilizing civil works and vegetative treatments to limit
            negative impacts; 3) undertaking maintenance and repairs in
            a timely fashion; 4) using vegetative treatments to
            stabilize side slopes or prevent erosion; and 5) using
            special treatments to overcome the problem of ground water,
            such as drains.

display_title.display_title:
Indonesia - Third National
            Program for Community Empowerment in Rural Areas Project :
            environmental assessment (Vol. 2) : Environmental management framework

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Third National Community
            Empowerment Program in Rural Areas Project : indigenous
            peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Third National
            Community Empowerment Program in Rural Areas (PNPM Rural
            III) Project is to reduce poverty and improve local-level
            governance in Indonesia through the provision of investment
            resources to support productive proposals developed by
            communities, using a participatory planning process. There
            are four particularly important concerns in how the project
            approaches indigenous communities: (i) developing
            dissemination and facilitation materials in collaboration
            with local communities (issues of language, graphics, etc);
            (ii) using appropriate, inclusive self decision-making
            mechanisms in environments where indigenous groups are
            politically and culturally marginalized; (i.e. the Papua
            Program); (iii) finding a balance so that groups (i.e.
            women) excluded from traditional institutions can also join
            project processes; and (iv) since Kecamatan Development
            Program (KDP), the project included several adaptations to
            address concerns that marginalized indigenous groups are
            especially vulnerable to problems of elite domination and
            corruption (by recruiting and training of facilitators from
            these communities, providing special logistical support for
            geographically and socially difficult area, having two
            village facilitators (a man and a woman) trained and
            mentored to allow them to gradually in charge for village
            meetings under PNPM rural planning and accountability
            meetings, village proposal writing team and village
            implementation committee comprise village elected team, etc).
